subshell failed</pre>
Like in a script as a whole, <tt>exit</tt> defaults to returning the exit status of the last-run command, and a subshell that does not have an explicit <tt>exit</tt> statement will return the exit status of the last-run command.
===Environment variables===
We have already seen that, when a program is called, it receives a list of arguments that are explicitly listed on the command line. What we haven't mentioned is that it also receives a list of name-value pairs called "environment variables". Different programming languages offer different ways for a program to access an environment variable; C programs can use <tt>getenv("<var>variable_name</var>")</tt> (and/or accept them as a third argument to <tt>main</tt>), Perl programs can use <tt>$ENV{'<var>variable_name</var>'}</tt>, Java programs can use <tt>System.getenv().get("<var>variable_name</var>")</tt>, and so forth.
In Bash, environment variables are simply made into regular Bash variables. So, for example, the following script prints out the value of the <tt>HOME</tt> environment variable:
<source lang="bash">#!/bin/bash echo "$HOME"</source>
The reverse, however, is not true: regular Bash variables are not automatically made into environment variables. So, for example, this script:
<source lang="bash">#!/bin/bash foo=bar bash -c 'echo $foo'</source>
will not print <tt>bar</tt>, because the variable <tt>foo</tt> is not passed into the <tt>bash</tt> command as an environment variable. (<tt>bash -c <var>script</var> <var>arguments…</var></tt> runs the one-line Bash script <tt><var>script</var></tt>.)
To turn a regular Bash variable into an environment variable, we have to "export" it into the environment. The following script ''does'' print <tt>bar</tt>:
<source lang="bash">#!/bin/bash export foo=bar bash -c 'echo $foo'</source>
Note that <tt>export</tt> doesn't just create an environment variable; it actually marks the Bash variable as an exported variable, and later assignments to the Bash variable will affect the environment variable as well. That effect is illustrated by this script:
<source lang="bash">#!/bin/bash foo=bar bash -c 'echo $foo' # prints nothing export foo bash -c 'echo $foo' # prints 'bar' foo=baz bash -c 'echo $foo' # prints 'baz' </source>
The <tt>export</tt> command can also be used to remove a variable from an environment, by including the <tt>-n</tt> option; for example, <source lang="bash" enclose="none">export -n foo</source> undoes the effect of <source lang="bash" enclose="none">export foo</source>. And multiple variables can be exported or unexported in a single command, such as <source lang="bash" enclose="none">export foo bar</source> or <source lang="bash" enclose="none">export -n foo bar</source>.
It's important to note that environment variables are only ever passed ''into'' a command; they are never received ''back'' from a command. In this respect, they are similar to regular Bash variables and subshells. So, for example, this command:
<source lang="bash">#!/bin/bash export foo=bar bash -c 'foo=baz' # has no effect echo "$foo" # print 'bar' </source>
prints <tt>bar</tt>; the change to <tt>$foo</tt> inside the one-line script doesn't affect the process that invoked it. (However, it ''would'' affect any scripts that were called in turn ''by'' that script.)
If a given environment variable is desired for just one command, the syntax <source lang="bash" enclose="none">var=value command</source> may be used, with the syntax of a variable assignment (or multiple variable assignments) preceding a command on the same line. (Note that, despite using the syntax of a variable assignment, this is very different from a normal Bash variable assignment, in that the variable is automatically exported into the environment, and in that it only exists for the one command. If you want avoid the confusion of similar syntax doing dissimilar things, you can use the common Unix utility <tt>env</tt> for the same effect. That utility also makes it possible to ''remove'' an environment variable for one command — or even to remove ''all'' environment variables for one command.) If <tt>$var</tt> already exists, and it's desired to include its actual value in the environment for just one command, that can be written as <source lang="bash" enclose="none">var="$var" command</source>.
An aside: sometimes it's useful to put variable definitions — or function definitions — in one Bash script (say, <tt>header.sh</tt>) that can be called by another Bash script (say, <tt>main.sh</tt>). We can see that simply invoking that other Bash script, as <tt>./header.sh</tt> or as <tt>bash ./header.sh</tt>, will not work: the variable definitions in <tt>header.sh</tt> would not be seen by <tt>main.sh</tt>, not even if we "exported" those definitions. (This is a common point of confusion: <tt>export</tt> exports variables into the environment so that other processes can see them, but they're still only seen by ''child'' processes, not by ''parents''.) However, we can use the Bash built-in command <tt>.</tt> ("dot") or <tt>source</tt>, which runs an external file almost as though it were a shell function. If <tt>header.sh</tt> looks like this:
<source lang="bash">foo=bar function baz () { echo "$@" }</source>
then this script:
<source lang="bash">#!/bin/bash . header.sh baz "$foo"</source>
will print <tt>'bar'</tt>.
===Scope===
We have now seen some of the vagaries of variable scope in Bash. To summarize what we've seen so far:
* Regular Bash variables are scoped to the shell that contains them, including any subshells in that shell. ** They are not visible to any child processes (that is, to external programs). ** If they are created inside a subshell, they are not visible to the parent shell. ** If they are modified inside a subshell, those modifications are not visible to the parent shell. ** This is also true of functions, which in many ways are similar to regular Bash variables. * Function-calls are not inherently run in subshells. ** A variable modification within a function ''is'' generally visible to the code that calls the function. * Bash variables that are exported into the environment are scoped to the shell that contains them, including any subshells ''or child processes'' in that shell. ** The <tt>export</tt> built-in command can be used to export a variable into the environment. (There are other ways as well, but this is the most common way.) ** They differ from non-exported variables only in that they are visible to child processes. In particular, they are still not visible to parent shells or parent processes. * External Bash scripts, like other external programs, are run in child processes. The <tt>.</tt> or <tt>source</tt> built-in command can be used to run such a script internally, in which case it's not inherently run in a subshell.
To this we now add:
* Bash variables that are localized to a function-call are scoped to the function that contains them, including any functions called by that function. ** The <tt>local</tt> built-in command can be used to localize one or more variables to a function-call, using the syntax <source lang="bash" enclose="none">local var1 var2</source> or <source lang="bash" enclose="none">local var1=val1 var2=val2</source>. (There are other ways as well — for example, the <tt>declare</tt> built-in command has the same effect — but this is probably the most common way.) ** They differ from non-localized variables only in that they disappear when their function-call ends. In particular, they still ''are'' visible to subshells and child function-calls. Furthermore, like non-localized variables, they can be exported into the environment so as to be seen by child processes as well.
In effect, using <tt>local</tt> to localize a variable to a function-call is like putting the function-call in a subshell, except that it only affects the one variable; other variables can still be left non-"local".
{{Bash Shell Scripting/tip|A variable that is set inside a function (either via assignment, or via a for-loop or other built-in command) should be marked as "local" using the built-in command <tt>local</tt>, so as to avoid accidentally affecting code outside the function, unless it is specifically desired that the caller see the new value.}}
It's important to note that, although local variables in Bash are very useful, they are not quite ''as'' local as local variables in most other programming languages, in that they're seen by child function-calls. For example, this script:
<source lang="bash">#!/bin/bash
foo=bar
function f1 () { echo "$foo" }
function f2 () { local foo=baz f1 # prints 'baz' }
f2</source>
will actually print <tt>baz</tt> rather than <tt>bar</tt>. This is because the original value of <tt>$foo</tt> is hidden until <tt>f2</tt> returns. (In programming language theory, a variable like <tt>$foo</tt> is said to be "dynamically scoped" rather than "lexically scoped".)
One difference between <tt>local</tt> and a subshell is that whereas a subshell initially takes its variables from its parent shell, a statement like <tt>local foo</tt> immediately hides the previous value of <tt>$foo</tt>; that is, <tt>$foo</tt> becomes locally unset. If it is desired to initialize the local <tt>$foo</tt> to the value of the existing <tt>$foo</tt>, we must explicitly specify that, by using a statement like <tt>local foo="$foo"</tt>.
When a function exits, variables regain the values they had before their <tt>local</tt> declarations (or they simply become unset, if they had previously been unset). Interestingly, this means that a script such as this one:
<source lang="bash">#!/bin/bash
function f () { foo=baz local foo=bip }
foo=bar f echo "$foo"</source>
will actually print <tt>baz</tt>: the <tt>foo=baz</tt> statement in the function takes effect before the variable is localized, so the value <tt>baz</tt> is what is restored when the function returns.
And since <tt>local</tt> is simply an executable command, a function can decide at execution-time whether to localize a given variable, so this script:
<source lang="bash">#!/bin/bash
function f () { if [[ "$1" == 'yes' ]] ; then local foo fi foo=baz }
foo=bar f yes # modifies a localized $foo, so has no effect echo "$foo" # prints 'bar' f # modifies the non-localized $foo, setting it to 'baz' echo "$foo" # prints 'baz'</source>
will actually print <pre>bar
baz</pre>
==Pipelines and command substitution==
As we have seen, a command's return value, taken strictly, is just a small non-negative integer intended to indicate success or failure. Its real output is what it writes to the standard output stream. By default, text written to the standard output stream is printed to the terminal, but there are a few ways that it can be "captured" and used as the command's true return value.
===Pipelines===
When a sequence of commands are linked together in a pipeline, the output of each command is passed as input to the next. This is a very powerful technique, since it lets us combine a number of small utility programs to create something complex.
===Command substitution===
Command substitution is a bit like variable expansion, but it runs a command and captures its output, rather than simply retrieving the value of a variable. For example, consider our <tt>get_password</tt> example above:
<source lang="bash">#!/bin/bash
function get_password ( ) # Usage: get_password VARNAME # Asks the user for a password; saves it as $VARNAME. # Returns a non-zero exit status if standard input is not a terminal, or if the # "read" command returns a non-zero exit status. { if [[ -t 0 ]] ; then read -r -p 'Password:' -s "$1" && echo else return 1 fi }
get_password PASSWORD && echo "$PASSWORD" </source>
There is really no reason that the caller should have to save the password in a variable. If <tt>get_password</tt> simply printed the password to its standard output, then the caller could use command substitution, and use it directly:
<source lang="bash">#!/bin/bash
function get_password ( ) # Usage: get_password # Asks the user for a password; prints it for capture by calling code. # Returns a non-zero exit status if standard input is not a terminal, or if # standard output *is* a terminal, or if the "read" command returns a non-zero # exit status. { if [[ -t 0 ]] && ! [[ -t 1 ]] ; then local PASSWORD read -r -p 'Password:' -s PASSWORD && echo >&2 echo "$PASSWORD" else return 1 fi }
echo "$(get_password)" </source>
To evaluate <tt>"$(get_password)"</tt>, Bash runs the command <tt>get_password</tt> in a subshell, capturing its standard output, and replaces <tt>$(get_password)</tt> with the captured output.
In addition to the notation <tt>$(…)</tt>, an older notation <tt>`…`</tt> (using backquotes) is also supported, and still quite commonly found. The two notations have the same effect, but the syntax of <tt>`…`</tt> is more restrictive, and in complex cases it can be trickier to get right.
Command substitution allows nesting; something like <tt>a "$(b "$(c)")"</tt> is allowed. (It runs the command <tt>c</tt>, using its output as an argument to <tt>b</tt>, and using the output of ''that'' as an argument to <tt>a</tt>.)
A command substitution can actually contain a sequence of commands, rather than just one command. The output of all of these commands is captured. As we've seen previously, semicolons can be used instead of newlines to separate commands; that is particularly commonly done in command substitution. A command substitution can even contain variable assignments and function definitions (though, since the substituted commands run within a subshell, variable assignments and function definitions inside the command will not be seen outside it; they are only useful if they are used inside the substituted commands).
==Shell arithmetic==
Arithmetic expressions in Bash are closely modeled on those in C, so they are very similar to those in other C-derived languages, such as C++, Java, Perl, JavaScript, C#, and PHP. One major difference is that Bash only supports integer arithmetic (whole numbers), not floating-point arithmetic (decimals and fractions); something like <tt style="white-space:nowrap">3 + 4</tt> means what you'd expect (7), but something like <tt style="white-space:nowrap">3.4 + 4.5</tt> is a syntax error. Something like <tt style="white-space:nowrap">13 / 5</tt> is fine, but performs integer division, so evaluates to 2 rather than to 2.6.
===Arithmetic expansion===
Perhaps the most common way to use arithmetic expressions is in ''arithmetic expansion'', where the result of an arithmetic expression is used as an argument to a command. Arithmetic expansion is denoted <tt style="white-space:nowrap">$(( … ))</tt>. For example, this command:
<source lang="bash">echo $(( 3 + 4 * (5 - 1) ))</source>
prints <tt>19</tt>.
===Numeric operators===
In addition to the familiar notations <tt>+</tt> (addition) and <tt>-</tt> (subtraction), arithmetic expressions also support <tt>*</tt> (multiplication), <tt>/</tt> (integer division, described above), <tt>%</tt> (the "remainder" operation; for example, 11 divided by 5 is 2 remainder 1, so <tt style="white-space:nowrap">11 % 5</tt> is <tt>1</tt>), and <tt>**</tt> ("exponentiation", i.e. involution; for example, 2<sup>4</sup> = 16, so <tt style="white-space:nowrap">2 ** 4</tt> is <tt>16</tt>).
The operators <tt>+</tt> and <tt>-</tt>, in addition to their "binary" (two-operand) senses of "addition" and "subtraction", have "unary" (one-operand) senses of "positive" and "negative". Unary <tt>+</tt> has basically no effect; unary <tt>-</tt> inverts the sign of its operand. For example, <tt style="white-space:nowrap">-(3*4)</tt> evaluates to <tt style="white-space:nowrap">-12</tt>, and <tt style="white-space:nowrap">-(-(3*4))</tt> evaluates to <tt>12</tt>.
===Referring to variables===
Inside an arithmetic expression, shell variables can be referred to directly, without using variable expansion (that is, without the dollar sign <tt>$</tt>). For example, this:
<source lang="bash">i=2+3 echo $(( 7 * i ))</source>
prints <tt>35</tt>. (Note that <tt>i</tt> is evaluated first, producing 5, and then it's multiplied by 7. If we had written <tt>$i</tt> rather than <tt>i</tt>, mere string substitution would have been performed; <tt>7 * 2+3</tt> equals 14 + 3, that is, 17 — probably not what we want.)
===Assigning to variables===
Shell variables can also be assigned to within an arithmetic expression. The notation for this is similar to that of regular variable assignment, but is ''much'' more flexible. For example, the previous example could be rewritten like this:
<source lang="bash">echo $(( 7 * (i = 2 + 3) ))</source>
except that this sets <tt>$i</tt> to <tt>5</tt> rather than to <tt>2+3</tt>. Note that, although arithmetic expansion looks a bit like command substitution, it is ''not'' executed in a subshell; this command actually sets <tt>$i</tt> to <tt>5</tt>, and later commands can use the new value. (The parentheses inside the arithmetic expression are just the normal mathematical use of parentheses to control the order of operations.)
In addition to the simple assignment operator <tt>=</tt>, Bash also supports compound operators such as <tt>+=</tt>, <tt>-=</tt>, <tt>*=</tt>, <tt>/=</tt>, and <tt>%=</tt>, which perform an operation followed by an assignment. For example, <tt style="white-space:nowrap">(( i *= 2 + 3 ))</tt> is equivalent to <tt style="white-space:nowrap">(( i = i * (2 + 3) ))</tt>. In each case, the expression as a whole evaluates to the new value of the variable; for example, if <tt>$i</tt> is <tt>4</tt>, then <tt style="white-space:nowrap">(( j = i *= 3 ))</tt> sets both <tt>$i</tt> and <tt>$j</tt> to <tt>12</tt>.
Lastly, Bash supports increment and decrement operators. The increment operator <tt>++</tt> increases a variable's value by 1; if it ''precedes'' the variable-name (as the "pre-increment" operator), then the expression evaluates to the variable's ''new'' value, and if it ''follows'' the variable-name (as the "post-increment" operator), then the expression evaluates to the variable's ''old'' value. For example, if <tt>$i</tt> is <tt>4</tt>, then <tt style="white-space:nowrap">(( j = ++i ))</tt> sets both <tt>$i</tt> and <tt>$j</tt> to <tt>5</tt>, while <tt style="white-space:nowrap">(( j = i++ ))</tt> sets <tt>$i</tt> to <tt>5</tt> and <tt>$j</tt> to <tt>4</tt>. The decrement operator <tt>--</tt> is exactly the same, except that it decreases the variable's value by 1. Pre-decrement and post-decrement are completely analogous to pre-increment and post-increment.
===Arithmetic expressions as their own commands===
A command can consist entirely of an arithmetic expression, using either of the following syntaxes:
<source lang="bash">(( i = 2 + 3 ))</source> <source lang="bash">let 'i = 2 + 3'</source>
Either of these commands will set <tt>$i</tt> to <tt>5</tt>. Both styles of command return an exit status of zero ("successful" or "true") if the expression evaluates to a non-zero value, and an exit status of one ("failure" or "false") if the expression evaluates to zero. For example, this:
<source lang="bash">(( 0 )) || echo zero (( 1 )) && echo non-zero</source>
will print this:
zero non-zero
The reason for this counterintuitive behavior is that in C, zero means "false" and non-zero values (especially one) mean "true". Bash maintains that legacy inside arithmetic expressions, then translates it into the usual Bash convention at the end.
===The comma operator===
Arithmetic expressions can contain multiple sub-expressions separated by commas <tt>,</tt>. The result of the last sub-expression becomes the overall value of the full expression. For example, this:
<source lang="bash">echo $(( i = 2 , j = 2 + i , i * j ))</source>
sets <tt>$i</tt> to <tt>2</tt>, sets <tt>$j</tt> to <tt>4</tt>, and prints <tt>8</tt>.
The <tt>let</tt> built-in actually supports multiple expressions directly without needing a comma; therefore, the following three commands are equivalent:
<source lang="bash">(( i = 2 , j = 2 + i , i * j ))</source> <source lang="bash">let 'i = 2 , j = 2 + i , i * j'</source> <source lang="bash">let 'i = 2' 'j = 2 + i' 'i * j'</source>
===Comparison, Boolean, and conditional operators===
Arithmetic expressions support the integer comparison operators <tt><</tt>, <tt>></tt>, <tt><=</tt> (meaning ≤), <tt>>=</tt> (meaning ≥), <tt>==</tt> (meaning =)</tt>, and <tt>!=</tt> (meaning ≠). Each evaluates to <tt>1</tt> for "true" or <tt>0</tt> for "false".
They also support the Boolean operators <tt>&&</tt> ("and"), which evaluates to <tt>0</tt> if either of its operands is zero, and to <tt>1</tt> otherwise; <tt>||</tt> ("or"), which evaluates to <tt>1</tt> if either of its operands is nonzero, and to <tt>0</tt> otherwise; and <tt>!</tt> ("not"), which evaluates to <tt>1</tt> if its operand is zero, and to <tt>0</tt> otherwise. Aside from their use of zero to mean "false" and nonzero values to mean "true", these are just like the operators <tt>&&</tt>, <tt>||</tt>, and <tt>!</tt> that we've seen outside arithmetic expressions. Like those operators, these are "short-cutting" operators that do not evaluate their second argument if their first argument is enough to determine a result. For example, <tt style="white-space:nowrap">(( ( i = 0 ) && ( j = 2 ) ))</tt> will not evaluate the <tt style="white-space:nowrap">( j = 2 )</tt> part, and therefore will not set <tt>$j</tt> to <tt>2</tt>, because the left operand of <tt>&&</tt> is zero ("false").
And they support the conditional operator <tt style="white-space:nowrap">''b'' ? ''e1'' : ''e2''</tt>. This operator evaluates <tt>''e1''</tt>, and returns its result, if <tt>''b''</tt> is nonzero; otherwise, it evaluates <tt>''e2''</tt> and returns its result.
These operators can be combined in complex ways:
<source lang="bash">(( i = ( ( a > b && c < d + e || f == g + h ) ? j : k ) ))</source>
===Arithmetic for-loops===
Above, we saw one style of for-loop, that looked like this:
<source lang="bash"> # print all integers 1 through 20: for i in {1..20} ; do echo $i done </source>
Bash also supports another style, modeled on the for-loops of C and related languages, using shell arithmetic:
<source lang="bash"> # print all integers 1 through 20: for (( i = 1 ; i <= 20 ; ++i )) ; do echo $i done </source>
This for-loop uses three separate arithmetic expressions, separated by semicolons <tt>;</tt> (and not commas <tt>,</tt> — these are completely separate expressions, not just sub-expressions). The first is an initialization expression, run before the loop begins. The second is a test expression; it is evaluated before every potential loop iteration (including the first), and if it evaluates to zero ("false"), then the loop exits. The third is a counting expression; it is evaluated at the end of each loop iteration. In other words, this for-loop is exactly equivalent to this while-loop:
<source lang="bash"> # print all integers 1 through 20: (( i = 1 )) while (( i <= 20 )) ; do echo $i (( ++i )) done </source>
but, once you get used to the syntax, it makes it more clear what is going on.
===Bitwise operators===
In addition to regular arithmetic and Boolean operators, Bash also offers "bitwise" operators, meaning operators that operate on integers ''qua'' bit-strings rather than ''qua'' integers. If you are not already familiar with this concept, you can safely ignore these.
Just as in C, the bitwise operators are <tt>&</tt> (bitwise "and"), <tt>|</tt> (bitwise "or"), <tt>^</tt> (bitwise "exclusive or"), <tt>~</tt> (bitwise "not"), <tt><<</tt> (bitwise left-shift), and <tt>>></tt> (bitwise right-shift), as well as <tt>&=</tt> and <tt>|=</tt> and <tt>^=</tt> (which include assignment, just like <tt>+=</tt>).
===Integer literals===
An integer constant is expressed as an ''integer literal''. We have already seen many of these; <tt>34</tt>, for example, is an integer literal denoting the number 34. All of our examples have been ''decimal'' (base ten) integer literals, which is the default; but in fact, literals may be expressed in any base in the range 2–64, using the notation <tt><var>base</var>#<var>value</var></tt> (with the base itself being expressed in base-ten). For example, this:
'''echo''' $'''((''' 12 '''))''' # use the default of base ten (decimal) '''echo''' $'''((''' 10#12 '''))''' # explicitly specify base ten (decimal) '''echo''' $'''((''' 2#1100 '''))''' # base two (binary) '''echo''' $'''((''' 8#14 '''))''' # base eight (octal) '''echo''' $'''((''' 16#C '''))''' # base sixteen (hexadecimal) '''echo''' $'''((''' 8 + 2#100 '''))''' # eight in base ten (decimal), plus four in base two (binary)
will print <tt>12</tt> six times. (Note that this notation only affects how an integer literal is interpreted. The result of the arithmetic expansion is still expressed in base ten, regardless.)
For bases 11 through 36, the English letters A through Z are used for digit-values 10 through 35. This is not case-sensitive. For bases 37 through 64, however, it is specifically the lowercase English letters that are used for digit-values 10 through 35, with the uppercase letters being used for digit-values 36 through 61, the at-sign <tt>@</tt> being used for digit-value 62, and the underscore <tt>_</tt> being used for digit-value 63. For example, <tt>64#@A3</tt> denotes 256259 (<span style="white-space:nowrap">62 × 64<sup>2</sup> + 36 × 64 + 3</span>).
There are also two special notations: prefixing a literal with <tt>0</tt> indicates base-eight (octal), and prefixing it with <tt>0x</tt> or <tt>0X</tt> indicates base-sixteen (hexadecimal). For example, <tt>030</tt> is equivalent to <tt>8#30</tt>, and <tt>0x6F</tt> is equivalent to <tt>16#6F</tt>.
===Integer variables===
A variable may be declared as an integer variable — that is, its "integer attribute" may be "set" — by using this syntax:
<source lang="bash">declare -i n</source>
After running the above command, any subsequent assignments to <tt>n</tt> will automatically cause the right-hand side to be interpreted as an arithmetic expression. For example, this:
<source lang="bash"> declare -i n n='2 + 3 > 4' </source>
is more or less equivalent to this:
<source lang="bash">n=$((2 + 3 > 4))</source>
except that the first version's <source lang="bash" enclose="none">declare -i n</source> will continue to affect later assignments as well.
In the first version, note the use of quotes around the right-hand side of the assignment. Had we written <tt style="white-space:nowrap">n=2 + 3 > 4</tt>, it would have meant "run the command <tt>+</tt> with the argument <tt>3</tt>, passing in the environment variable <tt>n</tt> set to <tt>2</tt>, and redirecting standard output into the file <tt>4</tt>"; which is to say, setting a variable's integer attribute doesn't affect the overall parsing of assignment statements, but merely controls the interpretation of the value that is finally assigned to the variable.
We can "unset" a variable's integer attribute, turning off this behavior, by using the opposite command:
<source lang="bash">declare +i n</source>
The <tt>declare</tt> built-in command has a number of other uses as well: there are a few other attributes a variable can have, and <tt>declare</tt> has a few other features besides turning attributes on and off. In addition, a few of its properties bear note:
* As with <tt>local</tt> and <tt>export</tt>, the argument can be a variable assignment; for example, <source lang="bash" enclose="none">declare -i n=2+3</source> sets <tt>$n</tt>'s integer attribute and sets it to <tt>5</tt>. * As with <tt>local</tt> and <tt>export</tt>, multiple variables (and/or assignments) can be specified at once; for example, <source lang="bash" enclose="none">declare -i m n</source> sets both <tt>$m</tt> integer attribute and <tt>$n</tt>'s. * When used inside a function, <tt>declare</tt> implicitly localizes the variable (unless the variable is already local), which also has the effect of locally unsetting it (unless the assignment syntax is used).
===Non-integer arithmetic===
As mentioned above, Bash shell arithmetic only supports integer arithmetic. However, external programs can often be used to obtain similar functionality for non-integer values. In particular, the common Unix utility <tt>bc</tt> is often used for this. The following command:
<source lang="bash">echo "$(echo '3.4 + 2.2' | bc)"</source>
prints <tt>5.6</tt>. Needless to say, since <tt>bc</tt> is not so tightly integrated with Bash as shell arithmetic is, it is not as convenient; for example, something like this:
<source lang="bash"> # print the powers of two, from 1 to 512: for (( i = 1 ; i < 1000 ; i *= 2 )) ; do echo $i done </source>
would, to support non-integers, become something like this:
<source lang="bash"> # print the powers of one-half, from 1 to 1/512: i=1 while [ $( echo "$i > 0.001" | bc ) = 1 ] ; do echo $i i=$( echo "scale = scale($i) + 1 ; $i / 2" | bc ) done </source>
Part of this is because we can no longer use an arithmetic for-loop; part of it is because referring to variables and assigning to variables is trickier now (since <tt>bc</tt> is not aware of the shell's variables, only its own, unrelated ones); and part of it is because <tt>bc</tt> communicates with the shell only via input and output.
==Input / Output==
===User=== ====Using whiptail==== Whiptail is a program that allows shell scripts to display [[w:Dialog box|dialog boxes]] to the user for informational purposes, or to get input from the user in a friendly way. Whiptail is included by default on [[w:Debian|Debian]]. :From the [http://www.tldp.org/LDP/Linux-Dictionary/html/w.html GNU/Linux Dictionary]: whiptail is a "dialog" replacement using newt instead of ncurses. :From its README: whiptail is designed to be drop-in compatible with dialog(1), but has less features: some dialog boxes are not implemented, such as tailbox, timebox, calendarbox, etc.
See [[Bash Shell Scripting/Whiptail]].
===Files=== ====Shell redirection==== In shells, redirection is used for file I/O. The most common usage of is to redirect standard streams (stdin, stdout and stderr) to accept input from another program via piping, to save program output as a file, and to suppress program output by redirecting a stream to <tt>/dev/null</tt>.

For example, if <tt>grep YES votes.txt</tt> returns <tt>0</tt>, then <tt>! grep YES votes.txt</tt> returns <tt>1</tt>, but is otherwise equivalent.</li> <li>Also supported by the <tt>[ ... ]</tt> builtin, and inside conditional expressions. For example, if <tt>[[ -e file.txt ]]</tt> is true, then <tt>[[ ! -e file.txt ]]</tt> is false.</li> <li>Also supported in arithmetic expressions. For example, if <tt>$i</tt> is nonzero, then <tt>$(( ! i ))</tt> is <tt>0</tt>.</li> <li>See also <tt>#!</tt> below.</li></ul></td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt>"…"</tt></td> <td><ul><li>Quotes an argument (or part of an argument) so that it is not split by whitespace into multiple arguments, but without preventing parameter expansion and command substitution internally.</li> <li>See also <tt>$"…"</tt> below.</li> </ul></td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt>#</tt></td> <td><ul><li>Introduces a comment (which continues to the end of the line). For example, the command <tt>foo bar baz # bip</tt> is equivalent to the command <tt>foo bar baz</tt>, because the comment <tt># bip</tt> is removed.</li> <li>Inside an arithmetic expression, an integer literal of the form <tt><var>b</var>#<var>n</var></tt> is interpreted in base <tt><var>b</var></tt>. For example, <tt>2#110110</tt> is binary 110110, i.e. fifty-four.</li> <li>See also <tt>#!</tt> below.</li> <li>See also <tt>$#</tt> below.</ul></td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt>#!</tt></td> <td><ul><li>Used at the very beginning of an executable script to specify the interpreter that should be used to run it. For example, if the first line of <tt>script.pl</tt> is <tt>#!/usr/bin/perl</tt>, and <tt>script.pl</tt> has executable permissions, then <tt>./script.pl</tt> is roughly equivalent to <tt>/usr/bin/perl ./script.pl</tt>.</li> <li>The first line of a Bash script is generally either <tt>#!/bin/bash</tt> or <tt>#!/bin/sh</tt>. (The former is generally considered preferable.)</li></ul></td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt>$</tt></td> <td><ul><li>Introduces various types of expansions, notably parameter expansion (as in <tt>$<var>var</var></tt> or <tt>${<var>var</var>}</tt>), command substitution (as in <tt>$(<var>command</var>)</tt>), and arithmetic expansion (as in <tt>$((<var>expression</var>))</tt>).</li></ul></td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt>$"…"</tt></td> <td><ul><li>A variant of <tt>"…"</tt> (see above) that supports locale-specific translation. (Unless you're writing scripts for use in multiple languages, e.g. both English and French, you don't need to worry about this.)</li></ul></td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt>$#</tt></tt></td> <td><ul><li>The number of positional parameters (arguments to a script or function). For example, if a script is invoked as <tt>script.sh a b c</tt>, then <tt>$#</tt> will be <tt>3</tt>. Builtins that modify positional parameters, such as <tt>shift</tt> and <tt>set</tt>, affect <tt>$#</tt> as well.</li></ul></td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt>%</tt></td> <td>The modulus operator. Returns the remainder resulting from integer division. E.g. 5%2 = 1</td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt>&</tt></td> <td>Ampersand. Commonly used to start a command in the background. E.g. firefox &</td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt>'</tt></td> <td>Single quote. Used to quote text literally.</td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt>(</tt></td> <td>Open parenthesis. Used to denote the beginning of a subshell, among other things.</td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt>)</tt></td> <td>Closing parenthesis. Used to denote the "EOF" of a subshell.</td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt>*</tt></td> <td>Asterisk. Denotes multiplication. E.g. 5*2 = 10</td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt>+</tt></td> <td>Plus. Denotes addition. E.g. 5+2 = 7</td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt>,</tt></td> <td>Comma. Used for separation. E.g. ls file{1,2,3}</td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt>-</tt></td> <td>Hyphen. Denotes subtraction. E.g. 5-2 = 3</td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt>.</tt></td> <td>Full Stop.</td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt>/</tt></td> <td>Forward slash. Denotes integer division (e.g. 5/2=2) or part of a path (e.g. /home/user)</td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt>:</tt></td> <td>Colon.</td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt>;</tt></td> <td>Semicolon. Separates lines if no newline/EOL exists. E.g. echo hello; echo world</td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt><</tt></td> <td>Open angle bracket. Used for input redirection</td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt>=</tt></td> <td>Equality sign. Used to assign variables and check equality</td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt>></tt></td> <td>Closing angle bracket. Used for output redirection.</td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt>?</tt></td> <td>Question Mark.</td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt>@</tt></td> <td>At sign. Typically used as a variable containing all arguments passed to the environment as $@</td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt>[</tt></td> <td>Open square bracket. Used as a more visually appealing alternative to test. E.g. if [ condition ] ; then etc</td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt>\</tt></td> <td>Backslash. Most commonly used for escaping. E.g. rm file\ with\ a\ bunch\ of\ spaces.txt</td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt>]</tt></td> <td>Closing square bracket. Closes test enclosures</td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt>^</tt></td> <td>Caret.</td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt>_</tt></td> <td>Underscore.</td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt>`…`</tt></td> <td><ul><li>Triggers command substitution; equivalent to <tt>$(…)</tt>, but is somewhat more error-prone.</li></ul></td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt>{</tt></td> <td>Open curly brace. Used for specific variable expansion. E.g. (where var = "hello ") echo "${var}world" will print "hello world", echo "$varworld" will generate an error, expecting a variable called varworld.</td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt>|</tt></td> <td>Pipe. Used for redirecting input to output. Specifically, it takes the output of the command on the left hand side, runs the program on the right side, and then passes the contents of the first command's output to the second, as if it were being typed from a keyboard. 'ls -l | grep Desk' is equivalent to running "grep Desk", and then manually typing what ls -l would have output. Every press of the return key would then trigger grep until ^D is pressed to pass the EOF.<!--I think that is a very intuitive way to think about it.--></td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt>}</tt></td> <td>Closing curly brace.</td> </tr>
<tr> <td><tt>~</tt></td> <td>Tilde. Typically used to refer to the home directory. Logged in as "mrwhite", cd ~ (or just cd) would go to /home/mrwhite. Logged in as another user, the same effect could be achieved with 'cd ~mrwhite'.</td> </tr>
</table>

revision.text:
Now that you've gotten the hang of 3D modeling, it's important to get some community feedback on your progress. Don't be an idiot and skip this part, or you'll regret it later. Basically this will help you track your progress and give you something that you'll be working on over a long term and something you'll be proud of.
* First, you need to come up with a project idea. You can choose your own modeling project, or choose one from the list below.
* Second, you need to create a model of your idea. Spend a couple of hours on it, and give it some details.
* Third, once you believe you've come far enough with the model, post it in the [http://blenderartists.org/forum/forumdisplay.php?s=b6a3696a3b803274bb7c1b49df9a22a2&f=16 Works In Progress] forum on BlenderArtists.org(formerly elysiun.com) (you will have to create an account if you haven't already). Post several screenshots of your model from within the Blender (note: creating screenshots is outside the scope of this wikibook, though see note lower down the page). You can post whatever subject and message with your posting that you would like, or you can use this suggested subject and message:
:Subject: Beginning Modeling Final Project - <project name>
:: Please assist me with any feedback on my model, keeping in mind that I am an absolute beginner still. I appreciate your help.
* Wait for feedback. It usually comes very quickly. If you have any questions about feedback that you are given, don't be afraid to ask your questions in the forum.
* When you and others that have viewed your work feel that you are ready, save your model in some place you can get back to easily. You will continue working on this project once you've learned some new skills.
* Move on to the next page.
(BTW. in Windows and/or maybe other OS, to take a screenshot press 'PrtScn' (PrintScreen). It will copy the screen to clipboard for you to paste in your favourite graphics application. This may not work in other OSs but try anyway. You can also create Blender screenshot directly from Blender using menu '''File>Dump 3DView...''' or '''File>Dump Screen...''' )
(In linux under the KDE I use ksnapshot, check under the graphics tab and see if you have it. If not it should be just a google search away :) gl and happy blendering)
(On Mac OS X, press Command (Apple) + Shift + 3 to do a full screen capture)
*List of ideas: *A Computer and keyboard *A fishing rod *A train engine *A skyscraper *A robot *A Tank (real or made up) *An airplane *A truck or car *Household appliances *A Weapon
{{BookCat}}
